item.title: Scraping bioRxiv
item.description: This post is the first of a series focusing on tracking preprints on bioRxiv. The motivation behind this and a more detailed explanantion can be found here. Scraping in R When I began to approach preprint tracking, the mysterious world of “HTML scraping” seemed like something that would help. Simply, scraping allows you to extract information from the underlying HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) documents that make up websites. HTML scraping seemed like a good idea for preprint tracking because: A) It doesn’t seem like there are simple/easy ways to access a bioRxiv database that holds such information (especially for someone with limited experience in this like me) and B) Whether or not the paper is published in a peer-reviewed journal is displayed clearly on each preprint’s page (see below on the webpage in red).

item.title: Keeping track of preprints
item.description: Premise For my first set of blog posts, I have decided to start a series about preprints. Awhile ago, an interesting question was brought up by Shannon Ellis in her wonderful blog post “Let there be preprint citations!" (emphasis is mine): Problem #2: Preprints often become peer-reviewed research. How will we keep track? Solution #2a (if this occurs during while the manuscript is being drafted): It is up to the author(s) to ensure that their manuscript is as up to date as possible upon submission for publication.

item.title: My first blog post!
item.description: Hello! If you haven’t been able to tell by the website already, my name is Paul Hook. I am a fourth year Ph.D. student in the Human Genetics program in the McKusick-Nathans Institute of Genetic Medicine at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. I am in Dr. Andy McCallion’s lab. You can learn a little more about me here, so I won’t go on and on in the inaugural blog post.

item.title: about
item.description: My name is Paul Hook. I am a fifth year Ph.D. student in the Human Genetics program in the McKusick-Nathans Institute of Genetic Medicine at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. I am in Dr. Andy McCallion’s lab and I am currently working on trying to elucidate the genetics that underlie Parkinson disease and other complex neurological disorders. I am especially interested in non-coding DNA and gene regulation. I have recently realized I enjoy sifting through big datasets and spending hours trying to make the perfect figures in R.

item.title: contact
item.description: Email me: phook2 [at] jhmi.edu I’m on Twitter: @pwhook Find my code and analyses on Github Check me out on Google Scholar Lets do cool stuff

item.title: papers
item.description: Grad school 2020 Hook, P.W., & McCallion, A.S. (2020). Leveraging mouse chromatin data for heritability enrichment informs common disease architecture and reveals cortical layer contributions to schizophrenia.Genome Research. Advanced online publication. <a href=“https://doi.org/10.1101/gr.256578.119 “target="_blank”>https://doi.org/10.1101/gr.256578.119 Github: https://github.com/pwh124/open_chromatin Data: Previous preprint versions can be found on bioRxiv. doi: <a href=“https://doi.org/10.1101/427484 “target="_blank”>https://doi.org/10.1101/427484 2018 McClymont, S.A., Hook, P.W., Soto, A.I., Reed, X., Law, W.D., Kerans, S.J., Waite, E.L., Briceno, N.J., Thole, J.F., Heckman, M.G., Diehl, N.

item.title: projects
item.description: Analysis of public mouse ATAC-seq data Github: https://github.com/pwh124/open_chromatin Data: This Github repo and Zenodo data repo are associated with <a href=“https://doi.org/10.1101/gr.256578.119 “target="_blank”>Hook and McCallion, 2020 Single-cell RNA-seq of dopaminergic neurons Github: https://github.com/pwh124/sc-da-parkinsons This Gitub repo contains code for analyses and figures associated with Hook, et al., 2018 Website: https://pwh124.github.io/sc-da-parkinsons/ I created this website from the Github repo above using the workflowr package. I wanted to create this website so that my data would be more accessible and reproducible.
